questions.question_text: Which three of the following statements are true regarding ACLs? (Choose three.)

choices.A: ACLs provide packet filtering for routers and firewalls to protect network segments that require more security.
choices.D: At a minimum, it is important to configure the ACLs on the network edge routers or firewalls.
choices.C: ACLs provide a basic level of security and control the packets that pass through the routers or firewalls, preventing them from getting to the different parts of the network.
choices.B: ACLs are used to perform stateful packets inspections and filtering on routers and firewalls.
choices.E: ACLs can be applied only at the inbound direction and not at the outbound direction.

discussion.content: There can be a lot of discussion about claim stated in answer D.

comments.content: I don't agree, ICMP should be included to support IP.

discussion.content: One could argue that instead of F, it should be C.

questions.question_text: Which four of the following are considered the main protocols of the Internet Protocol suite? (Choose four.)
Which three of the following options are methods that are used by an attacker while gathering network data? (Choose three.)

comments.content: i disagree. if an attacker can connect and disconnect cables, then whats the purpose of ping sweeps? or port scans? someone in any decent company with access to wiring closet has already the knowledge needed

discussion.content: The best hackers do everything from A to D, and in that order.

questions.question_text: Which one of the following utilities allows an attacker to scan the network in stealth mode?

discussion.content: Tip: Stealth mode is not actually stealthy

choices.C: security policy defined by the system administrator
choices.B: security policy defined by the owner of an object
choices.D: role of a user within an organization

questions.question_text: Based on which statement does the discretionary access control security model grant or restrict access?

discussion.content:
D.
"Discretionary access control (DAC) is a type of access control defined by the Trusted Computer System Evaluation Criteria[1] "as a means of restricting access to objects based on the identity of subjects and/or groups to which they belong. "
